comment._content: Bellissima!!!!!!!!!!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Presumably "later than 1886" is due to the cable tram being there.  it looks to me as if the railway station on the right (old Milsons Point station opened 1893) is not there - otherwise the photographer would have proudly included it in the picture.  So perhaps before 1893?  

Certainly before 1895 as the Colonial Secretary's Office has no dome.

I feel sorry for that tree - it needed re-potting!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Same subject from the left in 1900 - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3022875713/ Including the tree - good to see it survived another five years at least!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wait up! Someone DID re-pot that tree before 1900 - see the PhM photo at full zoomit - from.ph/28138 - the 'pot' is much wider. Unless it is oval shaped . . . .?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Alas! The poor tree did not survive till c.1905 - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2448050898/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ha! The tree, a Port Jackson Fig was famous and loved in its day - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14212920 . The tree blew down in a gale on 31/12/1900. History here - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18180029 and trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17705096 The above articles reproduce this photo, but do not agree on the date. One says " . . in the '80s" - the other "1891". (or the type of fig).

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It certainly was loved, thanks for adding these links.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Another slightly different view same vintage - www.cable-car-guy.com/images/nthsydneyferryterminus.jpg

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This article from the Australian Town & Country Journal in July 1900 includes a pic of the Milson's Point wharf and surrounds (including tree!). Presumably this pic was taken in ca. 1900 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71385116 ; UPDATE - This pic must have been in the T&CJ's photo library...it had previously appeared in an 1897 issue - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71293987 Here's a pic from a 1902 Sydney Mail (no tree) - news.google.com/newspapers?id=qxFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WZUDA...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Just found - this photo was reproduced in the SMH of 31/08/1929 p.13 as " MILSONS POINT IN 1891.... ...This photograph was taken by Mr. Sidney W. Jackson in 1891. The historic figtree mentioned in Mr. Conigrave's article and shown here was blown down later on. It never seemed to thrive after the wall was built round it. " - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16580235 More about the tree in an article on the same page - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16580224

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Sidney William Jackson (1873 - 1946) better known as an ornithologist and naturalist - adb.anu.edu.au/biography/jackson-sidney-william-6815 and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_William_Jackson

comment.author: 93911731@N08
comment._content: ...Tree looks very unhealthy ... no vibrancy ... thinning branches. Compare photos. Sad, sad, sad ... it SHOULD still be here now. Beautiful shape ... sad, sad, sad !!!

comment.author: 61739538@N08
comment._content: It wasn't the "pot" that killed the fig, it was the soil level being lowered by over a metre and cutting off all the roots that lead to its decline.  No wonder it fell over a few years later.
